subject: Re: speed
msgSnippet: Though Read s clames that Senior Quikskript was 50% more effective than T.O. are slightly exagerated Quickscript has two very good aspects- readability and
messageBody:
Though Read's clames that Senior Quikskript was 50% more effective
than T.O. are slightly exagerated Quickscript has two very good
aspects- readability and staying within the lines. Also, Pitman and
Handywrite use character size or thickness to indicate voicing, the
two Read-made systems (especially Shavian) use reversal. In all of
the shorthand systems I have seen so far S and Z (SAMPA, IPA [s] [z])
are one symbol. In Quickscript the verb "use" and the noun "use" are
written differently, not so in the various shorthands.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, matthew smith
<nerd_the_mighty@...> wrote:
>
> thank you for your input i think that i will learn both and see
which i like better
>
> Hermann Philipps <hphilipps@...> wrote: Although
Quikscript is faster than ordinary letters (once you are used
> to it) it may not be sufficiently fast for really speedy writing.
You
> could try Handywrite
(http://www.alysion.org/handy/handywrite.htm). It
> works without different pencil pressures.
>
> Hermann
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "nerd_the_mighty"
> <nerd_the_mighty@> wrote:
> >
> > hi im new to this group and am wondering about whether
quickscript is
> > a good thing to use for speed (when handwriten) because i am
trying to
> > find a fast way to take notes for classes ive looked into
pittman
> > gregg and teeline but i dont like them any suggestions on types
to
> > write if quickscript is not fast written
> >
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
